channel.title: Chapter 1 on Precalculus 1 - Functions
channel.description: Recent content in Chapter 1 on Precalculus 1 - Functions

item.title: 1.1 Sets & Numbers
item.description: Smithsonian Museum of Natural History, photo by Blake Patterson Introduction The Smithsonian in Washington, DC is one of the largest museums in the world, housing vast collections of rare and historically significant objects. The Air and Space collection, for example, holds the 1903 Wright Flyer, the first successful airplane, and the Apollo 11 Command Module from the first mission to the moon. Notable items in other collections include Abraham Lincolnâ€™s top hat, an original Kermit the Frog puppet, and the famous Hope Diamond.

item.title: 1.1 Sets & Numbers Practice

item.title: 1.2 Functions
item.description: Soda Vending Machine Japan Coast, photo by slackrhackr Introduction Each button on a vending machine corresponds to a particular snack inside the machine. The item you get depends on the button you push. When you press the button for a soda the machine should give you that soda, if it is functioning properly. In this section we'll see that mathematical functions connect things in a similar way. The Definition of a Function While no single definition can capture the full extent of the function concept, it is still important to start with one.

item.title: 1.2 Functions Practice
item.description: Identify Functions Exercise 1 Exercise 2 Exercise 3 Exercise 4 Exercise 5 Exercise 6 Vertical Line Test Exercise 7 Exercise 8 Exercise 9 Exercise 10 Function Notation Exercise 11 Exercise 12 Exercise 13 Exercise 14 Exercise 15 Exercise 16 Exercise 17

item.title: 1.3 Graphs of Functions
item.description: Roller coaster photo by dlohner on Pixabay Intro If you've ever ridden a roller coaster you know how it feels to crawl up a hill and rocket down the other side. You also know how your stomach floats at the top and sinks at the bottom. It would be a very boring ride if the track never changed direction. The twists and turns, peaks and valleys make a roller coaster exciting and give it character.

item.title: 1.3 Graphs of Functions Practice
item.description: Graphing Functions Exercise 1 Exercise 2 Exercise 3 Exercise 4 Reading the Graph of a Function Exercise 5 Exercise 6 Exercise 7 Exercise 8 Exercise 9 Exercise 10 Exercise 11 Exercise 12 Domain & Range from a Graph Exercise 13 Exercise 14 Exercise 15

item.title: 1.4 Transformations of Functions
item.description: Ice cream cones photo by silviarita on Pixabay Introduction When making ice cream, chefs often start with a basic recipe and then add in different amounts of special ingredients, like macadamia nuts or dark chocolate or berries. Experienced chefs know the effect that each addition will have before they even taste the finished product. In a very similar way, we can take basic functions and transform them into new functions by mixing in constants.

item.title: 1.4 Transformations of Functions Practice
item.description: Transformations of Functions Exercise 1 Exercise 2 Exercise 3 Exercise 4 Exercise 5 Exercise 6 Exercise 7 Exercise 8 Exercise 9 Exercise 10 Exercise 11 Exercise 12 Exercise 13 Exercise 14 Exercise 15 Horizontal & Vertical Stretches Exercise 16 Exercise 17

item.title: 1.5 Inverse Functions
item.description: Bora Bora, Tahiti photo by Julius Silver on Pexels Introduction Imagine that you flew to Tahiti for a vacation. After spending some time enjoying the white sandy beaches and crystal clear water, you might want to return home. To get back home you would need to find a return flight. In mathematics, a process that brings you back to where you started is called an inverse. In this section you will learn to recognize when a function has an inverse and how to find it.

item.title: 1.5 Inverse Functions Practice

item.title: 1.6 Measuring How Functions Change
item.description: iPod photo by mikefoster on Pixabay Introduction When the stock market opened on Monday, October 22, 2001, stock in Enron (a large Fortune-500 energy company) was trading for about $20 per share. At the same time stock in Apple (the electronics manufacturer) could also be purchased for $20. Without additional information, it would be natural to assume that state of both companies was the same. In reality, however, they were headed in opposite directions.
